mn4:2.1: This is the first time we have encountered a brahmin, or indeed any non-Buddhists, in the Majjhima. In contrast with the Dīgha, the Majjhima looks more inward to the Buddhist community, although of course with no shortage of exceptions. We meet Jāṇussoṇi several times in the suttas. His name is obscure, and according to the commentary it is a title awared the family priest (_purohita_) of Kosala. Perhaps we are to read _jāṇu_ as equivalent to _jana_, with _soṇi_ the Vedic _svani_ (“sound”), thus “famed among men”.
mn4:2.3: Bodhi, Nyanamoli, and Ṭhānissaro translate this as a question. However, there are none of the usual question markers and given the varied sequence as evident in the EA version (see Analayo) it seems likely that Horner was right to translate as a statement.
mn4:2.4:
This picks up from the previous sutta the themes of following the Buddha’s example 
 and of seclusion.
